head.title: The Death Penalty Is Beyond Repair

hedline.hl1: The Death Penalty Is Beyond Repair

abstract.p: Letter by William F Schulz of Amnesty Interntational says death penalty is unnecessary and beyond repair (S)

block.p: The application of the death penalty in the United States is biased against the poor and people of color, and characterized by a shocking number of erroneous convictions. And as you report (front page, Sept. 22), the presence of a death penalty does not decrease homicides in a state.

The application of the death penalty in the United States is biased against the poor and people of color, and characterized by a shocking number of erroneous convictions. And as you report (front page, Sept. 22), the presence of a death penalty does not decrease homicides in a state.

Earlier this month, the Justice Department issued a study showing that the application of the death penalty at both the federal and state levels depends more on race and geography than on the nature of the alleged crime. A recent Columbia Law School report concluded that capital sentences are ''persistently and systematically fraught with alarming amounts of error.''

What these studies show and what the American people are realizing is that the death penalty is unnecessary and beyond repair. There should be a moratorium on state and federal executions. Let's call the death penalty what it is: a human rights violation that must end once and for all.
The writer is executive director of Amnesty International U.S.A.
